captions.text: -Hi.

And welcome back for
another video by "Adopt
a 'Do Cute Girl's Hairstyles."

This morning, we are going to do
triple twists into twisty buns.

And I have pictures of this
on my blog from before,

but we're going to go ahead
and do the video since people
like the videos.
Turn your head this way.

I have wet her hair down and
I've parted it on one side.
So not in the middle.

I just put it on her natural
part, which is on the left.

You can part it
on whichever side.

Then I take from the
part down and section

off a little section and
just hold-- would you hand me
one of those rubber bands, babe?
-Big or small?
-This one.
Thank you.

Just put this back in a pony
to keep it out of the way.

So I begin at this top
right next to the part.
And you just start twisting.

And as you're twisting down--
fix that hair right there--

you just twist in
the other hair.

So you just add the hair in
as you go down, down, down.

And it creates a nice
little tight twist.

I twist from the front of
her face towards the back.

I suppose you can
do it the other way,

but it might look
a little funny.
And then have her hold.
Undo this.

And again, take a little
section, section it down.
Pull it back.

And again, go up at the
top and begin and just
start twisting the hair.

And as you're twisting
down, let your fingers
work the rest of the hair in.

I'm going to go back up and
twist that in a little farther.

And you create a
nice little twist.
There you go.
One more.
I like three.

I suppose you can
only do one or two,
but I personally like three.
So again, twist.

This one gets so
many comments when
we wear this out and about.

This hairdo looks much
harder and more complicated

than it really is, but it stays
really well put the whole day
and is very cute.

So now, I'm going to
just come back here

and just part the rest
of her hair in half.

Make sure you have
it parted even.

I'm going to take
the rest of her hair
and I like to wet it down.
It just holds in better.

Of course, the tween
version of this
would be to do it on dry hair.
Little bit softer twists.

Everything with the
tweens is a little
looser looking and softer.

But since she's younger--
and form a ponytail

and then just pull all three
twists back into the ponytail.

And secure it with
a rubber band.

Now, I'm going to go ahead and
twist the ponytail altogether

and twist it up and
around the rubber band.

And secure it with
another rubber band.

And then I like the
little ends fluffing out.

You can twist those
down in and just

secure them with the rubber band
as well so you don't see them

at all, but I think it's
fun to have them popped out.

And then repeat the
process on the other side.

So try to make your twists
even by parting approximately
where the other parts were.

Again, from front of
face to back of face.

So this morning is
a Sunday morning.

And we like to do the
hair on the Sunday morning

because it's a day when
daddy is home to film.
Hold.

So if you've noticed that my
outfits aren't changing that's
why.

I try to get more
than one video filmed.
Put that out of the way.
Begin to twist.
Last one.
Keep twisting.

This is a good one
for summertime.

Well, it's really a good
one for any time, honestly.

But we do this one a
lot for soccer games

because it stays in
so well or even swim

days or a day at the
beach this is a good one.

Although the only
thing I will say is you
must be careful about the parts.

Because there's a lot of them
so they have a tendency to get
sunburned.

So make sure you put some
sunscreen down those parts

if you're going to be out
in the sunshine too long.
Comb it up into a ponytail.
Add the twists in.
Do you have the big one?
Form a pony.
Twist it around.
Rubber band.
And then fluff the ends.
Oops.
Get my comb here.

And then secure it with a
little bit of hairspray.
And you're done.
Show daddy how cute.

title: Triple Twists to Twisty Buns | Updos | Cute Girls Hairstyles

comments.text:
If you ever read her blog, you see she is a MOM over the years she has 
accumulated different hair styles from what she's seen other places, and 
what she's come up with on her own. You don't need to be a professional 
hair stylist to give ideas, or even suggestions or safety hints! As for sun 
screen, Maisie, just put a little on your finger and rub into the places 
where the hair parts and exposes the scalp. As a natural red-head, this is 
something I've done before.﻿
comments.author: Tara P

comments.text:
Susan Michel its not like she's giving hair coloring advice or anything! 
What a strange thing to gripe about. Obviously she's worked with hair for 
years & probably knows how to do far more styles than a lot of stylists!! 
As a skin cancer survivor I'm grateful to hear her reminding people to put 
sunscreen on the hair part, which is something so many people would never 
think to do. ﻿
